Aatrox wants war because he thrives on it, Annie just wants to have fun (which can entail anarchy), Gangplank wants the world under his boot, Graves wanted revenge for being betrayed but now he's just a merc, Karthus wants to kill everyone and gift them with undeath since he views that as the perfect existence, Katarina just follows Noxus high command and values strength above all else (believing that being the strongest gives them the right to rule all), Kha wants to consume and evolve to be perfect, Rengar wants a challenge cuz stabby kitty loves the adrenaline rush of hunting, Thresh wants all the souls so he can spend eternity having fun torturing them, Tryndamere just wants peace in the Frejlyord, Vel wants to disintegrate everything so he can understand everything, Ziggs doesn't want destruction its just every time he invents something it exploded so he decided to start making bombs instead since that's what all his inventions wound up being anyway.

Some join for personal goals ({{champion:103}} become human without having to kill legions of humans, {{champion:101}} use the energy of the nexuses to break free from his bindings, {{champion:268}} gain assistance in bringing back Shurima, {{champion:420}} spread the glory of Nagakaborous, {{champion:157}} protection while he looks for the person who framed him)
Others join because they love to fight and wanted to find the strongest fighters ({{champion:24}} , {{champion:266}} , {{champion:62}} , {{champion:114}} )
Some joined because it looked fun ({{champion:1}} , {{champion:117}} , {{champion:150}} , {{champion:61}}  (the original Orianna wanted to join because it looked fun and it was a glory filled position but she died in a training accident causing her father to go mad with grief and make a robot in his daughters image who shares her dream))

and theres many more reasons too but I'm not going to go over all 130 some champions to explain them all :P

That's not what they said. They're main argument for removing the League was because, as long as the League was canon, they had to create reasons for the Champions to join or exist in the League and that was extremely limiting. Removing the League allows Riot to flesh out Champions' stories without having to force them back to the Institute of War in some way.
It's not limiting at all. Name one champion that is limited by this and I can easily give you the reason they'd join.

It's limiting because Riot always needs to come back to the Institute of War meaning Champions cannot development outside of the League. Look at Cho Gath for example; as long as he is in the League he doesn't exist except as a Champion. There's no room for expansion, especially since he's kept there forcibly.

The real question here is what lore is there to be derived from a roaming Cho'Gath? He eats everything. Same goes for Kog Maw. Such beings would fit much better into the old lore via background expansion rather than attempting to create lore past their captures -- which is pretty much exactly what all old lore consisted of outside of events. Is that a bad thing? I definitely don't think so seeing as typically when I read background lore I expect to see background lore.

TL;DR - Further Cho lore would be backsteps, telling tales of the Void or perhaps maybe he had some hand in what went on in the Howling Abyss, who knows?

Any other champion you think is unable to thrive in an IoW environment?

ChoGath is a highly intelligent void being and I believe most people forget that precisely because of the lack of expansion to his current. His goal is supposedly to consume the world, but do we really know? All Void creatures have a propensity to destroy but there seems to be overwhelming evidence that it's not simply for the sake of destruction (KogMaw, KhaZix, and VelKoz actively try to learn about their surroundings and adapt to Runeterra). As long as the Institute of War is canon, ChoGath has no story outside of his capture. In fact, many of the Void creatures and even the Void itself will remain unexplored. There are plenty of ways ChoGath can or could have interacted with Runeterra and the other Champions that would create a compelling story.

I agree that it's important that each Champion have a fundamental background to build upon but most of them are just uninspired (just look at Evelynn's lore; it doesn't actually provide anything substantial).

I'm sure you could come up with plenty of reasons for most Champions to join the League, that's not the issue. The issue is that that limits the storytelling. If the Institute of War was canon, everything would be stagnant and the story of Runeterra could not progress.

I like the movement Riot has made with their lore, though I am a little miffed at how long it has taken to come out. The newer Champions, like Bard and Kindred, have no place in an Institute of War. It just gets in the way of what's possible.

Yes, Cho is intelligent, which is entirely a point i thought of when thinking what he could be outside the rift. Well, nothing. He just wants to destroy everything. The best he can do is play the villain in some other champion's lore or an event.

Therefore, the concept of expanding his background is a much more attractive option (i would really like it if he actually did have a hand in the Howling Abyss).

And Evelynn's lore sucks because it was uninspired and written badly. As one of the earlier champs this sort of thing happens. But she could play all kinds of roles in the IoW. Summoners may be powerful, but they aren't gods. They can't control everything. Nor can they control each other.

There's plenty of lore possibilities for both the IoW itself and every champion in it. If they really wanted it gone they should have had an event where the summoners were all killed and the IoW destroyed. How is this possible? Well, another summoner war, brought about by thirst for power, manipulation, etc. Voidling invasion? Watcher's return? I fail to see the limitations here.
Shouldn't a taoist master have an answer on why people wage war?

Why are they fighting in Super Smash Bros?

League of Legends the game is separate from the lore. Some games integrate their gameplay and story (basically the game **is** the story), and some games segregate their game and story. 

I get it, we used to have that integration but Riot forcibly separated it. But other games do it, and there's nothing wrong with it.

A proper answer to your gf's question would be, "It's basically a battle arena for legendary warriors, and I am a summoner that is controlling them. The lore, the stories of which they are born in, are completely separate from the game. It's kind of like Super Smash Bros, because realistically Samus wouldn't be fighting Bowser in a Metroid game."

Though, Super Smash does have a reason, however small, for the fighting. It's a kid playing with models of these characters. 
League doesn't even have that.

We're all-powerful summoners controlling echoes of these legends, or something. It's just as complicated as a kid playing with toys, except instead of toys we're using magic.

Basically, to extend my explaination, let me try a side-by-side comparison:

Mario in SMB: A toy a kid is playing with to fight other toys.

Garen in LoL: A summoned hero a summoner is controlling to fight other summons in a battle arena.

Mario in his lore: A plumber that saves the princess of the Mushroom Kingdom when she gets kidnapped.

Garen in his lore: A hero of his country locked in a war against another, with possible ties to an assassin that goes against what Demacia stands for.

However, to be fair, it's not like we fight against Master Summoners in LoL like the Master Hand in SMB. Story mode, please Riot? D:
Except summoners don't exist anymore for like two years now.

Not in the lore, no. 

I don't think anyone is hearing what I'm saying :/

Yes, in the lore.

Most of the lores currently up are not canon anymore since the lore revamp.

Riot just didn't bother to write up new lore after they scrapped summoners and the Institute of War.
I get what you're saying (I think). Summoners don't exist in the lore; you're using the concept of a "summoner" to make a comparison to a child playing with models.

Basically.

Each of the toys in SSB have their own stories, but that's not their stories in SSB.

The story in SSBB is that a kid is using these toys that represent characters with their own stories from other games and pits them all against each other.

League of Legends however has no such kid. We are NOT all-powerful summoners. Those **_do not_** exist in the lore. Therefore we are merely imaginary beings taking characters from a generic fantasy world (as interesting as it comes, it's still the generic "magic land") and pitting them against each other.

And that's the problem. We don't exist anymore. It was both a completely literal and figurative disconnection between the lore and the player. The kid exists in smash, the summoners in league do not.
